fields.Description/Abstract: *This work is in progress. I have been working on the manuscript in Fall 2024. <br><br><br>Planar functions themselves cannot be bijections, and<br>there are known lower and upper bounds established on $V(f)$ for planar functions.<br>Since the planarity of a function (in the sense just defined) is invariant<br>under the addition of linear transformations and constants, this means that<br>for any planar function $f$ we actually have<br>$$\frac{q+1}{2}\le V(f+L) \le q - \frac{2(q-1)}{1+\sqrt{4q-3}}$$<br>for any linear transformation $L$. The lower bound was established independently by Kyureghyan and Pott \cite{kyureghyan08}, and Qiu, Weng, Wang and Xiang \cite{qiu07}, and later shown to be true for a much larger class of functions by Coulter and Matthews \cite{coulter11}. The upper bound was proved in \cite{coulter14c} by Coulter and Senger. <br>As an initial attempt to understand this phenomenon, we completely determine<br>the preimage distribution of<br>$x^2+L(x)$ for linear transformations over fields of order $p^2$, where $p$ is an odd prime.
